titles.main: Are Vancouver Parks' fish and chips on the endangered list?

content_elements.content:
I don�t get out to Vancouver�s park concessions too often. Usually, it is in the fall, when I grab a cup of hot cup of coffee to warm my hands as I walk along the Stanley Park seawall. I can�t remember the last time I bought fish and chips at the Lumberman�s Arch concession.

Refurbished neon sign for The Only Seafoods . Glenn Baglo, PNG

Former park board commissioner Christopher Richardson has noted in the past that if you didn’t get your fish and chips fix at Lumberman’s Arch �concession, you got it at The Only Seafood restaurant on Hastings Street. Unfortunately, that little hole-in-the-wall restaurant with its funky sign �just west of Main is no longer, another blow to Vancouver’s early fish port history.

But if Sarah Kirby-Yung, the newly-elected park board chairwoman has her way, some of the park board’s concessions will� have to drop fish and chips from their menu and fire up woks and frying pans�for�more diverse foods such as pad Thai and Chicken Tikka Massala.

When I interviewed her for a story about her proposal to revamp 14 of the concession stands, Kirby-Yung insisted she�s not trying to do away with all of the hallowed fish and chips concessions Vancouverites have come to love.

Instead, she argues we should also be celebrating some of the city�s diversity by bringing in healthier choices. Her plan is similar to one the Non-Partisan Association park board of 2006 tried, but failed to enact. It wanted to change the menus, consolidate the concessions under fewer operators, and do away with a warehouse it operates that gives concessionaires a bit of a break. It faced a backlash from both vendors and the public, who liked things the way they were.
Since then we�ve had additions to the menu of Fraser Valley corn, fruit cups and other local items, courtesy of the last Vision Vancouver board, whose mantra is to eat local.

For my story I interviewed Ruben Chapiel, who operates the Spanish Banks East concession for his daughter, Allice, who has the contract.� At 75 – he�ll be 76 next month – he�s witnessed the fickle nature of park-goers and notes that even on the coldest days fish and chips are his top seller.

He�s tried other healthier foods – the salads are hit in the summer – but an experiment with paninis was a flop – so he�s a bit worried that a park board plan to vary the menu could undermine the financial stability of some of the operators.
